questions.text: What is the approximate daily production of non-volatile (metabolic) acids in an adult human body?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) 70 to 100 mmol

 

Explanation:

 

  • Non-volatile (Metabolic) or fixed acids are produced from incomplete metabolism of carbohydrates (e.g. lactate), fats (e.g. ketones), and proteins (e.g. sulfate, phosphate).
  • In a typical diet, the body excretes about 40% of nonvolatile acids (around 30 mEq/day) through phosphate systems and 60% (approximately 50 mEq/day) through NH4+ excretion.
  • The net production of these fixed acids is about 70 to 100 mmol of H+ per day in an adult. This excludes lactate, as most of the lactate produced is metabolized and not excreted

 

12,000 to 24,000 mmol: Volatile (Respiratory) Acids(option A)

  • The main volatile acid is carbonic acid (H2CO3), which is more correctly referred to as carbon dioxide (CO2). CO2 is the end-product of the complete oxidation of carbohydrates and fatty acids.
  • Basal CO2 production is typically 12,000 to 13,000 mmol/day. However, actual daily CO2 production is usually higher, often in the range of 12,000 to 24,000 mmol/day, depending on metabolic activity levels.

 

Options C) and D) are incorrect values

questions.text: How does the excretion of ammonium (NH4+) contribute to bicarbonate (HCO3⁻) regulation in the kidneys?

choices.text: It directly increases the concentration of HCO3⁻ in the urine.
It generates HCO3⁻ , which is released into the bloodstream.
It decreases the overall HCO3⁻ reabsorption in the kidneys.
It prevents the secretion of H+ in the renal tubules.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) It generates HCO3⁻ , which is released into the bloodstream.

Explanation:

  • The kidneys filter bicarbonate (HCO3⁻) from the blood. Approximately 85% to 90% of bicarbonate is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule, while only about 10% is reabsorbed in the distal tubules and collecting ducts.
  • When NH4+ is excreted, it is produced from the deamination of amino acids. For each NH4+ ion excreted, one HCO3⁻ ion is generated and released into the bloodstream, helping to maintain acid-base balance.

 

 It directly increases the concentration of HCO3⁻ in the urine: While NH4+ is excreted in the urine, it does not directly increase the concentration of HCO3- in the urine. Instead, NH4+ excretion is linked to HCO3⁻ generation in the bloodstream (Option A).

 It decreases the overall HCO3⁻ reabsorption in the kidneys: The excretion of NH4+ does not decrease HCO3⁻ reabsorption; rather, it is part of the mechanism that helps maintain HCO3⁻ levels in the blood (Option C).

 It prevents the secretion of H+ in the renal tubules: The presence of NH4+ does not prevent the secretion of H+ ions. In fact, H+ ions are secreted into the tubular fluid, which is critical for HCO3⁻ reabsorption (Option D).


 

Factors Influencing Bicarbonate Excretion

questions.text: Which transport mechanism is primarily responsible for bicarbonate (HCO3⁻) reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Naᐩ-Hᐩ antiporter

 

Explanation:

 

Mechanism of Bicarbonate Reabsorption

Proximal Convoluted Tubule (PCT):

  • Naᐩ-Hᐩ Antiporter: The primary mechanism for bicarbonate reabsorption involves the Naᐩ-Hᐩ antiporter located on the apical surface of epithelial cells.
  • Carbonic Anhydrase: CA-4 catalyzes the hydration of CO2 to form carbonic acid (H2CO3), which dissociates into Hᐩ and HCO3-.This reaction occurs at the brush border of proximal tubular cells.
    • CA Traps CO2 in the tubular fluid, preventing its complete removal.
    • Facilitates the secretion of Hᐩ into the tubular lumen while retaining bicarbonate within the cell.
  • Higher permeability to Hᐩ and HCO3⁻ leads to a tubular fluid pH of approximately 6.5.
  • Bicarbonate ions diffuse into the interstitium, similar to Kᐩ ions.
  • Na+ and K+ Exchange: Naᐩ-Kᐩ ATPase pump is located in the basolateral membrane. Naᐩ enters the interstitium in exchange for Kᐩ via the Naᐩ-Kᐩ ATPase, maintaining Kᐩ concentration while decreasing Naᐩ concentration. (Option A)

Regulation of Acid-Base Balance

  • Urine acidification in the PCT is dependent on Naᐩ concentration.
  • Parathyroid Hormone (PTH): PTH inhibits the Naᐩ-Hᐩ exchanger in the PCT, affecting urine pH.
  • Carbonic Anhydrase Inhibitors: Drugs that inhibit carbonic anhydrase decrease urine acidification by impairing bicarbonate reabsorption.

 

 Cl⁻-HCO3⁻ antiporter, also known as Band 3 protein is a Chloride-bicarbonate exchanger at the basolateral membrane of the distal tubules and collecting ducts aids bicarbonate retention and urine acidification (Option C).

 

The Hᐩ-ATPase pump is located at the apical surface of the tubular cells of distal tubules and collecting ducts and facilitates ATP-driven transport of Hᐩ into the tubular lumen (Option D).

questions.text: What effect does aldosterone have on acid secretion in the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) and collecting duct (CD)?
questions.solution:
Acid Secretion at the DCT and CD

  • Mechanism:
    • Intercalated Cells: Produce Hᐩ and HCO3- from CO2, facilitated by carbonic anhydrase.
    • H+ Secretion: Via Hᐩ-ATPase or Kᐩ-Hᐩ ATPase into tubular fluid.
    • HCO3- Transport: Into interstitium via Cl⁻-HCO3⁻ antiporter.
  • Acidification of Tubular Fluid:
    • Low H+ permeability results in more acidic fluid (pH ~4.5), crucial for urinary buffer excretion.
    • H+ secretion is independent of Na+ concentration.
  • Role of Aldosterone:
    • Enhances acid secretion by increasing proton pump activity. (Option C)
  • Band 3 Protein (Anion Exchanger 1 or AE1):
    • Chloride-bicarbonate exchanger at basolateral membrane aids bicarbonate retention and urine acidification.
  • NH4+ Excretion:
    • Hᐩ combines with NH3 to form NH4ᐩ, which is excreted, and essential for acid-base balance.
  • Clinical Implications:
    • Reduced Hᐩ secretion decreases net acid excretion and affects HCO3⁻ buffering of non-volatile acids.

 

Decreases the activity of Hᐩ-ATPase (Option A): Aldosterone increases the activity of Hᐩ-ATPase but does not decrease it.

 

Inhibits the secretion of Hᐩ (Option B): Aldosterone enhances the secretion of Hᐩ, not inhibits it.

questions.text: What triggers the formation of ammonium ions (NH4ᐩ) and bicarbonate (HCO3⁻) in the ammonia buffer system?
questions.solution:
Acidosis stimulates the formation of ammonium ions (NH4ᐩ) and bicarbonate (HCO3⁻) in the ammonia buffer system. This process helps the body excrete excess acid and maintain acid-base balance.

 

BUFFERS

DESCRIPTION

Bicarbonate Buffer
  • Most powerful extracellular buffer system.
  • Composed of H2CO3 and NaHCO3
  • Buffers strong acids by forming H2CO3 and strong bases by reacting with H+ to form H2O and CO2.
  • Effective due to regulation by kidneys and lungs.

Phosphate Buffer
  • Composed of H2PO4⁻ and HPO4.
  • pK of 6.8, effective in slightly acidic urine.
  • Phosphate concentration increases in tubular fluid due to water reabsorption.

Ammonia Buffer
  • Composed of ammonia (NH3) and ammonium ion (NH4ᐩ).
  • In the liver, Glutamine metabolized to 2NH4ᐩ and 2HCO3−.
  • NH4ᐩ is secreted into the tubular lumen
  • HCO3− reabsorbed into blood.
  • Acidosis stimulates NH4ᐩ and HCO3⁻ formation; alkalosis decreases their formation.
  • The rate of NH4ᐩ excretion can increase significantly with chronic acidosis.

Others

(less significant)
  • Urate Buffer
  • Citrate Buffer

 

A) Increased sodium concentration: Sodium concentration does not directly trigger the formation of ammonium ions (NH4ᐩ) and bicarbonate (HCO3⁻) in the ammonia buffer system. Instead, sodium balance is primarily related to the regulation of fluid volume and blood pressure.

 

B) Alkalosis: In contrast, alkalosis decreases the formation of NH4ᐩ and HCO3⁻.

 

D) Dehydration: Dehydration primarily affects fluid balance and can lead to an increase in blood osmolarity. While severe dehydration can lead to metabolic disturbances, it does not specifically trigger the formation of NH4ᐩ and HCO3⁻ in the ammonia buffer system.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a prerequisite for a functional counter-current mechanism in the body?

choices.text: Parallel and opposite flow of fluids
Active transport of solutes across all segments

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Active transport of solutes across all segments
 

Explanation:


This is NOT a prerequisite for a functional counter-current mechanism. While active transport is essential in some segments, such as the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, which actively transports Na+ and Cl−, it is not required across all segments of the system. Passive transport and selective permeability are critical components.

 

Parallel and opposite flow of fluids: This is a fundamental requirement for a counter-current mechanism. In the kidneys, the descending and ascending limbs of the loop of Henle and the vasa recta have fluid flows in opposite directions, which maximizes the efficiency of exchange processes (Option A)

Close proximity and selective permeability of pathways: This selective permeability is crucial for the system's function. In the loop of Henle, the descending limb is permeable to water but not solutes, while the ascending limb is impermeable to water but actively transports solutes (Option B)

 A concentration gradient between inflow and outflow pathways: In the kidneys, the active transport of Na+ and Cl− from the ascending limb of the loop of Henle into the medullary interstitium creates the osmotic gradient that is essential for the counter-current mechanism to function effectively. The vasa recta helps maintain this gradient (Option D)

questions.text: What is the primary aim of the counter-current mechanism in the kidneys?

choices.text: To dilute urine for better excretion of waste products
To conserve sodium and chloride ions in the body
To concentrate urine and maintain fluid and electrolyte balance
To increase blood flow to the renal cortex

questions.solution:
The counter-current mechanism concentrates urine by creating a hyperosmotic environment in the renal medulla. This allows the kidneys to excrete waste products with minimal water loss, conserving water and maintaining fluid and electrolyte balance.

 

A) To dilute urine for better excretion of waste products: The counter-current mechanism aims to concentrate, not dilute, the urine. Dilution would result in a loss of excess water, which could lead to dehydration.

B) To conserve sodium and chloride ions in the body: While sodium and chloride reabsorption occurs during the process, the primary goal is not to conserve these ions but to create an osmotic gradient that facilitates water reabsorption.

D) To increase blood flow to the renal cortex: The counter-current mechanism primarily operates in the renal medulla and focuses on concentrating urine rather than regulating blood flow to the renal cortex.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a component of the counter-current multiplier system in the kidneys?

choices.text: Thick Ascending Limb (TAL) of the Loop of Henle
Thin Ascending Segment (ATS) of the Loop of Henle

questions.solution:
The CCD is involved in the reabsorption of water and electrolytes under the influence of hormones such as aldosterone and antidiuretic hormone (ADH). However, it is not directly part of the counter-current multiplier system. The counter-current multiplier specifically refers to the mechanisms occurring within the loop of Henle and associated structures in the medulla, not the cortical regions.


 

COUNTERCURRENT MULTIPLIER

Site

Function

Proximal Tubule
  • Delivers an isosmotic filtrate to the loop of Henle, with approximately 65% of filtered electrolytes and water reabsorbed.
  • The osmolarity here is around 300 mOsm/L, similar to plasma.

Thin Descending Limb of the Loop of Henle
  • Highly permeable to water due to the presence of aquaporin-1 (AQP-1) channels and mildly permeable to solutes like urea and sodium chloride.
  • As the filtrate moves deeper into the hyperosmotic medulla, water exits by osmosis, concentrating the tubular fluid.

Thin Ascending Limb of the Loop of Henle
  • Impermeable to water but permeable to solutes.
  • NaCl passively diffuses out, and some urea enters, contributing to medullary hyperosmolarity. (Option C)

Thick Ascending Limb of the Loop of Henle (TAL)
  • Impermeable to water and urea, actively transports NaCl, Kᐩ out of the tubule into the interstitium using the Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporter.
  • This action increases interstitial osmolarity and delivers hypotonic fluid to the distal tubule. (Option B)

Medullary Collecting Duct (MCD)
  • Under the influence of ADH, becomes permeable to water.
  • Water is reabsorbed from the MCD into the hyperosmotic medullary interstitium, concentrating the urine.
  • The MCD operates within the hyperosmotic environment established by the counter-current multiplier. (Option D)

questions.text: A 45 y/o patient presents with polyuria and polydipsia. Lab tests reveal a low urine osmolarity and a high plasma osmolarity. After administration of desmopressin (a synthetic analog of ADH), the patient's urine osmolarity increases significantly. Which of the following best explains the mechanism by which ADH improved the patient's condition?

choices.text: ADH increases the permeability of the ascending limb of the loop of Henle to water.
ADH decreases the active transport of sodium chloride in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle.
ADH increases the permeability of the collecting ducts to water.
ADH causes the osmolarity of the medullary interstitium to decrease rapidly.

questions.solution:
ADH increases the permeability of the collecting ducts to water by promoting the insertion of aquaporin-2 water channels into the apical membranes of collecting duct cells. This allows water to be reabsorbed from the tubular fluid into the hyperosmotic medullary interstitium, concentrating the urine and reducing urine volume.

A) The ascending limb of the loop of Henle is impermeable to water, a characteristic that is essential for the creation of a hyperosmotic medullary interstitium. ADH does not alter this permeability.

B)ADH does not affect the active transport of sodium chloride in the thick ascending limb. The active transport in this segment is necessary for establishing the osmotic gradient but is not regulated by desmopressin.

D)ADH does not decrease the osmolarity of the medullary interstitium. Instead, it facilitates water reabsorption in the collecting ducts, leveraging the existing high osmolarity of the medullary interstitium to concentrate the urine.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about urea transport in the kidneys is correct?

choices.text: UT-A1 and UT-A3 in the cortical collecting duct are regulated by aldosterone
Urea helps establish the osmotic gradient in the medullary pyramids but is not involved in urine concentration.
A high-protein diet reduces the kidneys' ability to concentrate urine.
UT-B is found in erythrocytes and the descending limbs of the vasa recta.

questions.solution:
UT-B is indeed found in erythrocytes and the descending limbs of the vasa recta.

Role of Urea in Kidney Function:

Functions:

  • Osmotic Gradient: Urea helps establish the osmotic gradient in the medullary pyramids.
  • Concentrated Urine: Contributes to forming concentrated urine in the collecting ducts. (Option B)

Urea Transport:

  • Mediated by: Urea transporters (UT-A isoforms).
  • Types:
    • UT-A1 to UT-A4: Found in kidneys.
    • UT-B: Found in erythrocytes and descending limbs of the vasa recta.
  • Key Transporters in Collecting Duct:
    • UT-A1 and UT-A3: Found in the medullary collecting ducts. Regulated by vasopressin. (Option A)

Regulation:

  • Vasopressin (ADH): Increases during antidiuresis, raising urea levels in the medullary interstitium, and enhancing the kidney’s urine concentrating capacity.

Impact of Diet:

  • High-Protein Diet: Increases urea filtration, enhancing urine concentration ability. (Option C)
  • Low-Protein Diet: Decreases urea filtration, reducing urine concentration ability.

questions.text: Which of the following substances plays the most crucial role in establishing and maintaining the hyperosmotic medullary interstitium?
questions.solution:
Urea is the most important substance for establishing and maintaining the hyperosmotic medullary interstitium. It significantly contributes to the osmotic gradient and urine concentration by:

  • Urea recycling: Urea is reabsorbed in the collecting ducts and secreted into the loop of Henle. This recycling helps to maintain a high concentration of urea in the medulla.
  • Osmotic Gradient: The high concentration of urea in the medullary interstitium creates an osmotic gradient. This gradient allows for the reabsorption of water from the collecting ducts, concentrating the urine.
  • Water Reabsorption: The osmotic gradient established by urea, along with sodium and other solutes, helps in reabsorbing water from the filtrate, making the medullary interstitium hyperosmotic.

A) Sodium is involved in creating the osmotic gradient but is not the most crucial substance for maintaining it.

B) Potassium plays a role in ionic transport esp. In the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, but is not the primary substance for the hyperosmotic gradient.

D) Chloride is involved in the osmotic gradient but is not as critical as urea for maintaining the hyperosmotic medullary interstitium.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is responsible for maintaining the counter-current exchange mechanism in the kidney?
questions.solution:
The vasa recta maintains the osmotic gradient through countercurrent exchange.

 

A) The loops of Henle are responsible for creating the osmotic gradient (countercurrent multiplier system) but not for maintaining it.

B) The collecting ducts use the osmotic gradient to concentrate urine but do not maintain the gradient.

D) The glomerulus is involved in the filtration of blood to form urine but does not maintain the osmotic gradient in the medulla.

Counter-Current Exchange Mechanism in the Vasa Recta

 

Aspect of Vasa Recta

Details

Function

  • Maintains the osmotic gradient established by the loops of Henle, crucial for concentrated urine production.

Structure
  • Hairpin-loop blood vessels that descend and ascend alongside the loops of Henle.

Descending Limb
  • Solutes (NaCl and urea) diffuse from the interstitium into the vasa recta.
  • Water moves out of the vasa recta into the interstitium due to the osmotic gradient.
  • Result: Blood becomes more concentrated as it descends.

Ascending Limb
  • Solutes diffuse from the vasa recta into the interstitium.
  • Water moves from the interstitium into the vasa recta.
  • The ascending vasa recta are fenestrated to facilitate this exchange.

Net Effect
  • Role: Prevents dissipation of the osmotic gradient.
  • Outcome: Maintains the hypertonicity of the medulla, essential for water reabsorption and concentrated urine production.

Conclusion:
  • Works with the loops of Henle to establish and maintain medullary osmotic gradient
